data.text: Touring Bike and Bags/Panniers on Amtrack Trains?

Has anyone ever taken their bicycle on Amtrack? They say you have to remove all panniers and bags before loading. What do you do with all those bags after you take them off the bike? Do you take them on as carry on or do you have to check them? That would be 5 bags.

Yes. I left some of the gear on my bike. They actually stowed my bike in the last car (luggage) so nobody was in there. I carried on my panniers and a small back pack. There was no extra charge. It was actually pretty smooth and great!

data.text: I haven't been on that train but I'm assuming they don't have major size constraints. Some shorter distance trains are just self-serve parking on hooks on most cars, longer distance trains will have a luggage car you take your bike to (you'll likely need to lift your bike head height, and they'll have a 50lb weight limit- last time I did one of those that was enough weight for my bike plus a lot of my light, volumous gear (clothes, tent, sleeping bag). Check the particular route on the Amtrak site, they each have their own name, it'll give specifics on amenities.

data.text: I do this often, and will be doing it on Friday. The panniers, trunks bags, and pretty much everything but water bottles, and the tiny underseat repair kit need to come off. Often, the front wheel needs to come off, so have a hex tool if that will be required. The bags can almost always go onto a very nearby luggage rack or the shelf above the seats. ￼if you can lift the fully loaded bike onto the train, do that, and then pull off the luggage and toss it into a luggage area. You should feel lucky getting this arrangement as otherwise, I’ve been left holding my bike upright where a wheelchair should go for hours at a time. Ultimately, each conductor has complete discretion over how to treat your bicycle, so I advise a very positive attitude and extreme politeness at all times.

data.text: I took Amtrak from Memphis to Chicago and Chicago to DC and DC to Chicago and Chicago to St. Louis this summer. Each time they told me to roll my touring bike on the train, fully loaded. They had an entire luggage car for bikes and they told me to lay the bike down except for the last time when I went from Chicago to St. Louis. That time they told me to lean it against the wall in the luggage car (still fully loaded). Each time i was told to lay it down,, i removed my panniers and set them next to my bike.. this was not because i was told to but because i didn't want my bike laying on top of my panniers and then the connecting points might break with all the weight on top of them (i took them off because of personal preference). The last time,, qhen I was told to leave the bike standing,, i fully expected it to have been thrown onto its side during the trip (the train is very bumpy and jerks around a lot). However,, when i went to the car to Retrieve my bike,, it was still standing. Not one time was i required to remove my panniers though...
